ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Knowledge of Russian history and different historical methods towards approaching this field.
Learned an unbelievable amount about Russian history, and was equipped with the tools  the lenses  to make sense of such a vast, magnificent, and misunderstood national story.
Writing short IDs and longer essays and getting through large readings quickly and thoroughly.
Russian political, social, cultural and economic history from 1801-1922.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Wish the lecture slides were more than just pictures and that the lectures went more chronologically instead of thematic. I had trouble understanding the Professor at times due to his mumbling and I didnt find the lectures very engaging but I think thats because they are too long for the 11:35-12:50 block. Words on slides definitely help me follow the lecture more and stay more engaged.

Strengths: The material was interesting and fairly interdisciplinary; I enjoyed many of the readings. Weaknesses: Lectures tended to drag on sometimes and they were not very interactive. It would have been helpful to have more signposting of important content in the lectures. I also would have preferred a grading scheme with less weight on the exams (especially the final exam) -- perhaps weekly discussion posts or a short writing assignment for 10-15% of the course grade would have helped even things out without substantially increasing the workload.

Lectures very engaging,  interesting photos, sometimes names were not included in PowerPoint and hard to transcribe. Perhaps a master list of all proper names so that students are better able to spell them.
Loved the time we spent in the Beinecke.  I only wish we had more time with primary sources.

Strengths were that we covered very interesting topics and sections were very useful. Weaknesses was that it was a bit boring sometimes. Could be improved with more PowerPoint power rather than just speaking

Professor Antonov gives enjoyable lectures with interesting content. The lack of supplement (i.e., lecture notes, list of terms) for the lectures made it difficult to know which topics could be used for ID questions on exams. The discussion section was more thematic and technical (historiography), which was useful as a history student, but left the reading largely unadressed. Discussion posts or an adjustment to the section priorities could help make the readings more important. The Buskovitch textbook was more important to the course than the Antonova guide, so their status as recommended and required materials respectively should be reversed.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, this class is a good overview of imperial Russian history. The workload is not too heavy, though the grading was stringent at times. This class is a solid history lecture course for a student from any year/major.
I would, its an interesting period.
Yes  to anyone interested in the mystery of Russia, and her transition from autocracy to communist oligarchy.
Yes. The subject matter is dramatic and compelling, and Professor Antonov presents it in detailed and friendly lectures. I looked forward to going to class.
